componenttext: It is very helpful. Maybe just lastly I will turn it over, I think that some of the capacity that you have had feeding the Chilean market was really ceded from North America, and I guess related to that, I'm curious on your strategy for Chambord, it seems like you have many lower-cost mills in your system that would likely come on before Chambord would. Given your somewhat cautious statements about buying into the recovery, or strong recovery in housing starts, how do you think about the future in that mill?

componenttext: Well, to your first point, we only moved about 4 million feet from North America down to Chile, which was to help until we could get (inaudible) up. To your second question, I think first on our radar, which would be obvious is that we did spend a couple of hundred million dollars on building Clarke County. And that will be our most important issue to try to get utilized as the market comes back to us.

componenttextpreview: I'm not saying that. What we have felt so far is just a slight imbalance between what we thought we could produce, and what was being asked of us. But in terms of any great underlying pull, I mean I think the numbers speak for themselves. We finished the
componenttext:
I'm not saying that. What we have felt so far is just a slight imbalance between what we thought we could produce, and what was being asked of us. But in terms of any great underlying pull, I mean I think the numbers speak for themselves. We finished the first quarter at - at an annualized rate of 530,000 single starts. So that is not terribly robust.
What we are trying to figure out is was any of that pull forward from these tax incentives, and then what is going to happen in historically Q3, which is prime building time. But we have seen permits go up just a little bit, but nothing that would knock your socks off. So as I said in my prepared remarks, I don't have a consensus forecast that says single family starts are all in that we're even going to crack 700,000 this year.
With (inaudible) being the outlier, and they are saying we will end the year at 870. So right now we are in a wait-and-see mode, and we're being quite careful.

componenttext: Paul, the only thing I would say to that is that we did see both January and February starts to get adjusted upwards in later months, and I wouldn't be surprised if March gets adjusted upwards.

componenttext:
Well, we said for 2010 is we would be in the 20 million to 25 million and I have no expectations to be any different from that. Next year, probably the biggest piece is the completion of the Brazilian acquisition. We have 75% of that mill, and there is simultaneously put-call in November of next year. So I would anticipate that we would pick up the other 25% of that mill. And that is in the neighborhood of probably 18 to 25, somewhere in there.
So that will certainly be in the plan, and then I think we have talked about some of the maintenance we needed to do on the presses, which are - that is probably the biggest maintenance expense you have in an OSB mill. And we do have a press or two that we are going to have to look at over the next two years. I don't know if that will be 2011 or 2012, and those are generally right around $15 million to redo all that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Louisiana-Pacific Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Anita, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would now like to turn the call over
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Louisiana-Pacific Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Anita, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Curt Stevens, the Executive Vice President of Administration and Chief Financial Officer. Please proceed.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much and thanks all of you for joining us on this conference call to discuss our results for the first quarter of 2010. As the operator said, I'm Curt Stevens, Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Rick Frost, LP's CEO, as well as
componenttext:
Thank you very much and thanks all of you for joining us on this conference call to discuss our results for the first quarter of 2010. As the operator said, I'm Curt Stevens, Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Rick Frost, LP's CEO, as well as Mike Kenny and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact. I'll begin the discussion with the review of our financial results for the first quarter of 2010; then I'll follow this with comments on some of our individual segments and selected balance sheet items. Rick will then take over and give you the weather report for national and then discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating; his perspective on our most recent operating results and his thoughts on the outlook for the remainder of 2010.
As we've done in the past, we've opened up this call to the public and are doing a webcast. This can be accessed at our website, www.lpcorp.com. Additionally, to help with the discussion, we have provided our presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I'll be referencing these slides in my comments. We had filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information, and we just filed our Form 10-Q for the quarter.
First thing on this slide, I'd like to remind all participants about the forward-looking statements comment that is included on Slide 2 of the presentation. Results of, be aware of our discussion, of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached has some of the necessary reconciliations, and those have been supplemented by the Form 8-K that we filed this morning. I'm not going to reread this statements but I am going to incorporate it with these references. 
Slide 4 of the presentation is a discussion of our Q1 2010 results compared to the same quarter last year and the prior quarter. Reporting today a net loss for the fourth quarter of $23 million or $0.18 per diluted share. Our net sales from continuing operations of nearly $300 million for the quarter. For the same period last year, we reported a net loss of $30 million or $0.29 per diluted share on sales from continuing operations of $206 million.
Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was a positive $3 million in the quarter compared to a loss of $25 million in the first quarter of 2009. There was some movement in the tax rate on continuing operations between the quarters. The effective tax benefit rate in Q1 was 31%. This is primarily the result of the blended rate between jurisdictions with profits from foreign subsidiaries, tax and lower rates and losses in North American operations. Q1 of 2009, the tax benefit rate was 39%, basically, the statutory rate. Has the tax benefit rate in Q1 been the same as last year, net earnings per share would have been improved about $0.03 a share.
Let me now discuss performance each of our segments. Slide 5 of the presentation is a summary of OSB. OSB had an operating loss of $5 million in the quarter compared to a $24 million operating loss in Q1 of 2009. For the quarter, we had a 34% increase in volume and an average sales price that was 26% higher in the same quarter last year. This resulted in a $24 million improvement in earnings and adjusted EBITDA. The strengthening of the Canadian dollar, which increases our cost more than revenue due to sales being in the U.S., further our earnings in this segment by about $5 million compared to Q1 of last year. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations in the OSB segment for the quarter was a positive $4 million compared to a loss of $17 million in Q1 of last year.
Compared to Q4 of 2009, volumes were lower by 14% while pricing increased by 22%. Volumes in Q1 were constrained by the availability of logs in the U.S. South, due to extremely wet weather conditions that occurred during the quarter. 
Slide 6 of the presentation is our Siding segment, which includes our SmartSide and CanExel Siding products and commodity OSB produced at our Hayward mill. For the first quarter, Siding had operating income of $9 million, significantly better than the $2 million recorded in the same quarter last year. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations in the Siding segment was $14 million compared to $7 million in Q1 of 2009. For the quarter, sales were up 20% and unit volumes were better by 29% in SmartSide and down by about 15% in CanExel compared to the same quarter last year. Reductions in volume for our CanExel product line is caused by our decision not to run one of the production lines while working on process improvements. This has limited our available product and customers in our location in CanExel.
For the quarter, SmartSide average sales prices were up slightly due to product mix with individual product pricings remaining relatively flat. CanExel prices show a pretty significant increase of 24%, but this is largely due to this product being sold in Canada and the strengthening of the Canadian dollar increase the U.S. sales price.
Slide 7 of the presentation, our engineered wood, which includes I-Joist, Laminated Strand Lumber, produced at our Houlton, Maine facility, Laminated Veneer Lumber plus other related products. Segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi JV are under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. For Q1, EWP recorded a loss of $7 million compared to a loss of $9 million in Q1 of last year. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations in the EWP segment was a negative $3 million, about half of what we recorded in Q1 of 2009 and Q4 of 2009.
Volumes of I-Joist were up significantly, 88%, while LVL/LSL were up 45% compared to the same quarter last year. The increase were tied to the increase in housing as well as during the quarter, we did see significant inventory building in the channel after dramatic reductions in 2009. Pricing was down slightly in I-Joist but up about 4% in LVL/LSL.
Our other building products. This category includes our interior moulding business, our South American operations and the U.S. GreenFiber Joint Venture in some non-operating facilities. Overall, we were slightly positive in the first quarter of 2010 as compared to income of $1.6 million first quarter of last year. For the quarter, sales for these operations were $41 million, up 45% from the $28 million recorded in Q1 of last year. 
Some other items. We did have a small foreign exchange gain in the quarter compared to $2.6 million gain in the same quarter last year. And then investment income in the quarter was about flat between periods, with returns down significantly but cash balances were higher. Interest expense was nearly $17 million in the quarter compared to $13 million in Q1 of 2009. This is primarily due to the higher cost refinancing that we completed late in Q1 of 2009. 
Slide 8 of the presentation shows some balance sheet items. Cash, cash equivalents, investments of restricted cash were $414 million into the quarter, working capital about $520 million. We had net cash over debt of $136 million, and capital expenditures were relatively modest $4 million in the quarter. Book value per ending share was $9.73.
I do want to mention as I did in our earnings call at the end of February that we did have a balance sheet growth that occurred in Q1 and was reflected retrospectively for prior periods. This was due to a change in accounting standard. We added back our previously qualified special purpose entity, an entity called LP Plywood, that was off-balance sheet and now it's back on the balance sheet. This entity was put in place in 2003 to defer the income taxes paid on the sale of LP's southern timberlands. By adding these back, we increased our assets by $368 million, increased our liability by a like amount and reduced equity by about $1 million.
The overall transaction has been disclosed since the inception in our footnotes but is now included in the balance sheet. This is the note, the associated debt had little or no recourse to LP as it is backed by a letter of credit, which is subsequently backed by cash. 
A few other comments before give to Rick, our federal tax refund, as we discussed in our last call, we did do a rap in filing 2009 federal income tax return and received a refund of about $47 million during the quarter. The balance sheet shows the remaining income tax receivable of about $6 million, and that will come back to LP over the next year or so. On the auction rate securities, based on valuations received from third parties, we did increase in the value of this portfolio by about $10 million in the quarter. And as you know, we are continuing to pursue the litigation filed against the principal issuers of these instruments. 
With that, let me turn over to Rick.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. It is drizzling here in Nashville, but we are drawing out after a week of sunshine last week. I'm sure that you did see in the news that we had severe weather and a lot of rain in the middle Tennessee area last weekend, and we had
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. It is drizzling here in Nashville, but we are drawing out after a week of sunshine last week. I'm sure that you did see in the news that we had severe weather and a lot of rain in the middle Tennessee area last weekend, and we had plenty of, I guess, unprecedented nature. It was the worst flooding in history. I am happy to report and relieved to report that we were fortunate that no LP employee suffered significant flood damage, but the town will take some time to recover.
I want to begin my brief prepared remarks this morning by adding a little bit of color in Q1 but not be redundant to what Curt has already said. On the safety front, we got up to a great start in the year with only two recordable injuries across our system in Q1 and a TIR of 0.23. Other most significant event was that our Carthage OSB mill was the first OSB mill in history in North America to exceed 1 million incident free work hours. 
Overall, financially, we did eke out our first positive adjusted EBITDA quarter Q1 since 2006, which felt good. The housing market ended the quarter with seasonally adjusted single-family starts of about 530,000. Each of our three core businesses did improve financially from Q1 of '09, which was granted a pretty low hurdle to jump over. But they also improved over Q4 of 2009 as well.
Make a few comments on each of our reporting segments for Q1. OSB did surprise us in Q1. Our customer's needs were more robust than we had anticipated going into the quarter. Random links sprint across the six different sales regions moved to upward, $60 to $65 on the 716 [indiscernible] bases during the quarter. Because of the lag effect, which is the time between order and delivery, we weren't able to capture all of that move, but what we did capture helped us considerably. 
Our Hanceville OSB Alabama mill was down 42 days in Q1 for log outages, resulting from weather that was adverse to logging. Our TechShield Radiant Barrier OSB roof sheathing was up 50% over Q1 '09, and our TopNotch Sub-Flooring was up 24% from the same quarter last year. We did have two mills that we're indefinitely shut during the quarter, Chambord and Clark County. And the rest of our mills ran on various shifting schedules.
In Siding, our SmartSide volume was up about 20% over Q1 2009, with slightly stronger sales price due to mix, and we think that bodes well for us for the rest of the year. As Curt mentioned, our CanExel fine fiber product remains on allocation as we work to get our production scheduling back in balance. 
In Engineered Wood Products, the segment which is most heavily tied to new residential construction, we improved, which means we lost less money. At these volume levels, this is still a distressed business segment. Plaguing this business at present are the lack of starts and component raw material prices [audio gap] which are outstripping finished product pricing. 
As you know, I-Joist is made from OSB web stock and flanged lumber and LVL is made from peeled veneer. All three of these core components have increased substantially in price, more so than finished product pricing. 
In Chile, which I had an opportunity to visit in the first quarter, the earthquake affected our Lautaro mill adversely with about 17-day outage. But at present, both of our Chilean mills are running full, to feed the reconstruction efforts that is needed there. 
I'll spend a few moments looking forward in terms of what we see coming at us and then we'll open it up to questions. Obviously, the recent run-up in OSB pricing is going to positively affect the financial performance of our OSB business and LP overall in Q2. It has certainly been unexpected, but even at these demand and takeaway levels, it is very significant to us. But the housing market has experienced a welcome bump, if you will. However, from what I read, it is unlikely that substantial recovery towards the base underlying housing demand will be significant in 2010. I just reviewed a recent composite of the 2010 start forecast put together by APA, and that still doesn't break the 700,000 start level for 2010. Although RISI is still the outlier on this, having the end of the year start level at about 850,000. 
Couple of questions for us are yet unanswered. First, is how much of the current housing activity is a pull-forward cost by tax incentives. And the second is the channel building a little bit more of a position for the summer. Meanwhile, we are still looking at four large problems in the eyes of four that we have been looking at for a year now. The first is high unemployment, which last week came in at 9.9%; continued foreclosures; the excess of for-sale inventory of existing homes and in general, slower household formation. And because of these elements, we're still being quite cautious in our optimism around this recovery. 
That said, I'll turn it back over to Curt for the question period.

componenttext: Well, we had anticipated as we put our production scheduling together, a pretty lackluster first quarter, and demand came out as a little bit heavier than what we thought. We were only able to meet that demand as we had put production on. And when demand's a little bit higher than the ability to supply it, the traded commodity that moves it forward. And so it, I think one of the analysts wrote about demandless recovery, it wasn't huge. It wasn't demand that we felt back several years ago, but it was a little bit more than we could supply. That allowed our traders the opportunity to ask more for the product out in future weeks.

componenttext: Right. I continue to look at that as well, Gail. Financing continues to get in our way. We haven't had any of the buyers, the potential buyers of the two biggest assets, fall out. But it's been slow in gathering the cash. The asset sale we sold was a relatively small one. But we're still anticipating it's going to come in the next quarter. But I said that last quarter, too. headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Mark, I'll take a shot at that and then if I miss something, Curt can fill in the holes. If you look at Q1, you guys get various amounts of information, but I'll refer to Random Lengths’ print. The year, North Central began on a 7/16 basis at 182.
componenttext: Yes. Mark, I'll take a shot at that and then if I miss something, Curt can fill in the holes. If you look at Q1, you guys get various amounts of information, but I'll refer to Random Lengths’ print. The year, North Central began on a 7/16 basis at 182. And I think quarter ended North Central 7/16 at 248. There are six different sales regions. And prices during the quarter varied between $10 and $15 up or down from each other in those sales regions. In the first quarter, the North Central was higher than all other regions, except for Western Canada. So a weighted average of sales may not equal the North Central pricing that some people seem to pick and look at obsessively. There's also a lag on pricing for open market wood. The way this works is that as order files extend, an order taken in one week may not actually be delivered for 4 weeks. So in a climbing pricing environment, this creates a lag in terms of getting what may print on a Friday. It may take you, however long your order file is out to capture that particular price. So if the market moves very, very quickly, you stay behind it. There's another influence that we had in terms of looking at that and that is that our value-added products tend to lag the market as well because the price in these products changes less rapidly. We did have a high component of value-added in Q1 with TechShield and TopNotch. And then finally, I think the other thing that influences price, particularly as price becomes higher, is that there are discounts on contracted wood on a percentage basis. So at a higher number those percentages are higher dollars. So that's what happens when the market moves very rapidly in the up direction.

componenttext: I had a question similar to the question on the order backlogs and how it affects the OSB price. Can you help us understand your raw material pulpwood costs? And whether we’ve seen the full effect of the higher pulpwood costs or whether there's more of that in front of us?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, in Q1, if we take the volumes that we purchased in Q1 of 2010 and apply pricing from last year to that, we're actually, we’re slightly positive in wood costs. The problem we had in Q1 was getting the wood. There wasn't any wood available, and
componenttext: Actually, in Q1, if we take the volumes that we purchased in Q1 of 2010 and apply pricing from last year to that, we're actually, we’re slightly positive in wood costs. The problem we had in Q1 was getting the wood. There wasn't any wood available, and that's why we had the downtime in the southern mills. But in general, because we operate both, as you know, in Canada and the U.S. in the lake states, we do a lot of logging during the winter in the north and that wasn't affected by the weather at all. So our costs are actually down a little bit. And as I look forward, I think they're going to be relatively flat, maybe up a little bit in Q2, but not a lot.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rick, I don't know if you care to comment on Chile and Brazil. Maybe you can touch on the earthquakes and what that's done, if anything, to the supply chain. What you're seeing on the marketplace. And just your progress on your Chile, Brazilian strategy?
componenttext: Rick, I don't know if you care to comment on Chile and Brazil. Maybe you can touch on the earthquakes and what that's done, if anything, to the supply chain. What you're seeing on the marketplace. And just your progress on your Chile, Brazilian strategy?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd be happy to. I think in terms of Chile, from what we can tell, it looks like about 300,000 residences were destroyed in that earthquake, which is somewhere in the neighborhood of 10 years worth of building. So in terms of what that's done for us,
componenttext: Yes. I'd be happy to. I think in terms of Chile, from what we can tell, it looks like about 300,000 residences were destroyed in that earthquake, which is somewhere in the neighborhood of 10 years worth of building. So in terms of what that's done for us, if you remember, on the last call, I said we had just started Lautaro, which is our second mill up in hopes of running it for the rest of the year. We now feel quite confident that we will run both mills full out for a considerable period of time to help in that reconstruction. So we did start Lautaro up between Christmas and New Year's. Right after the earthquake, we added the fourth shift there as quickly as possible. So both Pangui and Lautaro are running full. The other positive thing out of this catastrophe was that wood construction held up quite well. So we think that it will continue to help us in our effort to convert building practices in Chile. We did send about 4 million feet down from Canada to Chile in the immediate relief effort. And with some help to our Brazilian operation, we're moving a couple thousand cubic meters a month over from Brazil. So Chile looks to be full speed ahead with both mills for the foreseeable future, meaning, I would think at least a couple of years. In Brazil, we are running our Ponta Grossa mill at about 50% of capacity. When we bought that mill, it was in need of some improvement. We do have one dryer and one thermal oil system, which is down. And we are looking to, perhaps, start that dryer and that thermal oil system up somewhere in the fourth quarter to continue to fill in the success that we're having in selling OSB for non-construction purposes in Brazil. In a concurrent effort, we are working through the bureaucratic red tape to qualify a building system in Brazil, what we're calling, an OSB building system, which is if we’re successful there would allow us to then put LP OSB into that building system. There's a huge pent-up demand in Brazil, as I talked about last year and why we went there, currently, of about 7 million homes. And the need is projected for about 18 million homes over the next decade. So we think that that's going to continue to get more attractive for us. But right now, we're caught in this bureaucratic red tape. In Brazil, they don't approve single products. In their regulatory environment, they approve building systems. So we've been working on that now for about 5 or 6 months. And hopefully, we’ll break through sometime this year.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think some of the capacity, now that you've had feed-in with Chilean market, was really seeded from North America. And I guess related to that, I'm curious on your strategy for Chambord. It seems like you have lower cost mills in your system that would
componenttext: I think some of the capacity, now that you've had feed-in with Chilean market, was really seeded from North America. And I guess related to that, I'm curious on your strategy for Chambord. It seems like you have lower cost mills in your system that would likely come on before Chambord would. Given your summer cautious statements about buying into the recovery or a strong recovery in housing starts, how do you think about the future of that mill?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, to your first point, we only moved about 4 million feet from North America down to Chile, which was to help until we could get Pangui up. To your second question, I think first on our radar, which would be obvious is that we did spend a couple hundr
componenttext: Well, to your first point, we only moved about 4 million feet from North America down to Chile, which was to help until we could get Pangui up. To your second question, I think first on our radar, which would be obvious is that we did spend a couple hundred million dollars on building Clarke County. And that will be our most important issue to try to get utilized as the market comes back to us.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of, Lotsen [ph] talked about this supply-related pricing increases in OSB. What have you guys seen on the demand side, especially from your customers? Is it higher pull-throughs? Are you seeing things recover slightly faster than the current
componenttext: And in terms of, Lotsen [ph] talked about this supply-related pricing increases in OSB. What have you guys seen on the demand side, especially from your customers? Is it higher pull-throughs? Are you seeing things recover slightly faster than the current numbers indicate?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not seeing that. What we have felt so far is just a slight imbalance between what we thought we could produce and what was being asked of us. But in terms of any great underlying pull, I mean I think the numbers speak for themself. We finished the fir
componenttext: I'm not seeing that. What we have felt so far is just a slight imbalance between what we thought we could produce and what was being asked of us. But in terms of any great underlying pull, I mean I think the numbers speak for themself. We finished the first quarter at 500, at an annualized rate of 530,000 single starts. So that's not terribly robust. What we're trying to figure out was any of that pull forward from these tax incentives and then what's going to happen in historically Q3, which is prime-building time. But we've seen permits go up just a little bit, but nothing that would knock your socks off. So as I said in my prepared remarks, I don't have a consensus forecast that says single-family starts or all-in that we're even going to crack 700,000 this year with RISI being the outlier and their saying we’ll end the year at 870. Right now, we're in a wait-and-see mode and we're being quite careful.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the only thing I would say to that is we did see both January and February starts get adjusted upwards in later months. I wouldn't be surprised if March gets adjusted upward.
componenttext: Well, the only thing I would say to that is we did see both January and February starts get adjusted upwards in later months. I wouldn't be surprised if March gets adjusted upward.

componenttext: As you think about your capital spending, and you might have mentioned this earlier and I missed it. What does it look like? Not only for this year, but as you think about 2011? I know it's early days, but you're probably starting to think about it. And I mean sort of what kind of range do you think we can see next year? Or do you think the market is so good that you might pick it up substantially? Or are you going to be more cautious?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we said for 2010 is would be in the $20 million to $25 million. And I have no expectations it’s going to be different than that. Next year, probably the biggest piece is the completion of the Brazilian acquisition. We have 75% of that mill and then
componenttext: What we said for 2010 is would be in the $20 million to $25 million. And I have no expectations it’s going to be different than that. Next year, probably the biggest piece is the completion of the Brazilian acquisition. We have 75% of that mill and then there is a simultaneous put-call in November of next year. So I’d anticipate we'd pick up the other 25% of that mill. And that's in the neighborhood of probably 18 to 25, somewhere in there. That would certainly be in the plan. I think we've talked about some of the maintenance we need to do on the presses, which are that's probably the biggest maintenance expense you have in OSB mill. And we do have a press or two that we’re going to have to look at over the next two years. I don't know if that'll be a 2011 or 2012. And those are generally right around $15 million to redo all that. I don’t have anything of great significance because we have existing capacity in front of each one of our businesses.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now as you think about your, obviously, as you said next on your plate in terms of ramping up it’s the demands there. We see housing starts recovered nicely would be Clarke County, but what would sort of be behind that? Would there be other plants that
componenttext: Now as you think about your, obviously, as you said next on your plate in terms of ramping up it’s the demands there. We see housing starts recovered nicely would be Clarke County, but what would sort of be behind that? Would there be other plants that you’ve had down for a period of time that you would put sort of next in line?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the two that are in line are Clarke County and Chambord. And I think what Rick said is we’d certainly like to get a return on our investment in Clarke County. I mean you don’t have to be a genius to figure out why we've made Athens and Silsbee,
componenttext: Well, the two that are in line are Clarke County and Chambord. And I think what Rick said is we’d certainly like to get a return on our investment in Clarke County. I mean you don’t have to be a genius to figure out why we've made Athens and Silsbee, Texas indefinitely or permanently curtailed because the Clarke County mill can satisfy those two market areas.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then when you look at the [indiscernible], I know you talk about this receivable you put back like $400-some million on your balance sheet. A) Was that tied to timber sales in the past? And when will that become cash?
componenttext: And then when you look at the [indiscernible], I know you talk about this receivable you put back like $400-some million on your balance sheet. A) Was that tied to timber sales in the past? And when will that become cash?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. It was a 2003 timber sale that we did. So there’s a note receivable and note payable with an investment by LP of about $45 million. So the receivable is greater than the payable. When we did that in 2003, the rules required us to make that an off-b
componenttext: Yes. It was a 2003 timber sale that we did. So there’s a note receivable and note payable with an investment by LP of about $45 million. So the receivable is greater than the payable. When we did that in 2003, the rules required us to make that an off-balance sheet transaction, a qualified special-purpose entity. They changed the rules effective January 1, which changed the rules back to where it used to be. And so we had to add those back onto the balance sheet.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And when did they turn to cash?
componenttext: And when did they turn to cash?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: It was a bullet 15-year. So in 2018, what’ll turn into cash for us is the $44 million investment. The rest will self-liquidate.
componenttext: It was a bullet 15-year. So in 2018, what’ll turn into cash for us is the $44 million investment. The rest will self-liquidate.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that’s in, like you said, 2018?
componenttext: And that’s in, like you said, 2018?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: 2018, right. As then as you know, we’ll owe the deferred tax then, too. So we’ll get the cash in, but we’ll have the deferred tax on the gain.
componenttext: 2018, right. As then as you know, we’ll owe the deferred tax then, too. So we’ll get the cash in, but we’ll have the deferred tax on the gain.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's roughly how much?
componenttext: And that's roughly how much?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's in the 10-K. I don't have it right in front of me. Remember there's three different transactions, there's the California, the two California sales and this one that are all in that deferred tax. I don't have the schedule right in front of me. But if
componenttext: It's in the 10-K. I don't have it right in front of me. Remember there's three different transactions, there's the California, the two California sales and this one that are all in that deferred tax. I don't have the schedule right in front of me. But if you give Mike a call, I think it’s in the K.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Louisiana-Pacific Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Anita, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would now like to turn the call over
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Louisiana-Pacific Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Anita, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Curt Stevens, the Executive Vice President of Administration and Chief Financial Officer. Please proceed.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much and thanks all of you for joining us on this conference call to discuss our results for the first quarter of 2010. As the operator said, I'm Curt Stevens, Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Rick Frost, LP's CEO, as well as
componenttext:
Thank you very much and thanks all of you for joining us on this conference call to discuss our results for the first quarter of 2010. As the operator said, I'm Curt Stevens, Chief Financial Officer, and with me today are Rick Frost, LP's CEO, as well as Mike Kenny and Becky Barckley, our primary Investor Relations contact. I'll begin the discussion with the review of our financial results for the first quarter of 2010; then I'll follow this with comments on some of our individual segments and selected balance sheet items. Rick will then take over and give you the weather report for national and then discuss the general market environment in which LP has been operating; his perspective on our most recent operating results and his thoughts on the outlook for the remainder of 2010.
As we've done in the past, we've opened up this call to the public and are doing a webcast. This can be accessed at our website, www.lpcorp.com. Additionally, to help with the discussion, we have provided our presentation with supplemental information that should be reviewed in conjunction with the earnings release. I'll be referencing these slides in my comments. We had filed an 8-K this morning with some supplemental information, and we just filed our Form 10-Q for the quarter.
First thing on this slide, I'd like to remind all participants about the forward-looking statements comment that is included on Slide 2 of the presentation. Results of, be aware of our discussion, of our use of non-GAAP financial information included on Slide 3 of the presentation. The appendix attached has some of the necessary reconciliations, and those have been supplemented by the Form 8-K that we filed this morning. I'm not going to reread this statements but I am going to incorporate it with these references. 
Slide 4 of the presentation is a discussion of our Q1 2010 results compared to the same quarter last year and the prior quarter. Reporting today a net loss for the fourth quarter of $23 million or $0.18 per diluted share. Our net sales from continuing operations of nearly $300 million for the quarter. For the same period last year, we reported a net loss of $30 million or $0.29 per diluted share on sales from continuing operations of $206 million.
Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations was a positive $3 million in the quarter compared to a loss of $25 million in the first quarter of 2009. There was some movement in the tax rate on continuing operations between the quarters. The effective tax benefit rate in Q1 was 31%. It's primarily the result of the blended rate between jurisdictions with profits in foreign subsidiaries, tax at lower rates and losses in North American operations. Q1 of 2009, the tax benefit rate was 39%, basically, the statutory rate. Had the tax benefit rate in Q1 been the same as last year, net earnings per share would have been improved by about $0.03 a share.
Let me now discuss the performance of each of our segments. Slide 5 of the presentation is a summary of OSB. OSB had an operating loss of $5 million in the quarter compared to a $24 million operating loss in Q1 of 2009. For the quarter, we had a 34% increase in volume at an average sales price that was 26% higher than the same quarter last year. This resulted in a $24 million improvement in earnings and adjusted EBITDA. The strengthening of the Canadian dollar, which increases our costs more than revenue due to sales being in the U.S., hurt our earnings in this segment by about $5 million compared to Q1 of last year. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations in the OSB segment for the quarter was a positive $4 million compared to a loss of $17 million in Q1 of last year.
Compared to Q4 of 2009, volumes were lower by 14% while pricing increased by 22%. Volumes in Q1 were constrained by the availability of logs in the U.S. South, due to extremely wet weather conditions that occurred during the quarter. 
Slide 6 of the presentation is our Siding segment, which includes our SmartSide and CanExel Siding products and commodity OSB produced at our Hayward mill. For the first quarter, Siding had operating income of $9 million, significantly better than the $2 million recorded in the same quarter last year. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations in the Siding segment was $14 million compared to $7 million in Q1 of 2009. For the quarter, sales were up 20% and unit volumes were better by 29% in SmartSide and down by about 15% in CanExel compared to the same quarter last year. Reductions in volumes for our CanExel product line was caused by our decision not to run one of the production lines while working on process improvements. This has limited our available product and customers are in allocation in CanExel.
For the quarter, SmartSide average sales prices were up slightly due to product mix with individual product pricings remaining relatively flat. CanExel prices show a pretty significant increase at 24%, but this is largely due to this product being sold in Canada and the strengthening of the Canadian dollar increased the U.S. equivalent sales price.
Slide 7 of the presentation, our Engineered Wood, which includes I-Joist, Laminated Strand Lumber, produced at our Houlton, Maine facility, Laminated Veneer Lumber plus other related products. Segment also includes the sale of I-Joist and LVL products produced by the Abitibi JV are under a sales arrangement with Murphy Plywood. For Q1, EWP recorded a loss of $7 million compared to a loss of $9 million in Q1 of last year. Adjusted EBITDA from continuing operations in the EWP segment was a negative $3 million, about half of what we recorded in Q1 of 2009 and Q4 of 2009.
Volumes of I-Joist were up significantly, 88%, while LVL/LSL were up 45% compared to the same quarter last year. The increase were tied to the increase in housing as well as during the quarter, we did see significant inventory building in the channel after dramatic reductions in 2009. Pricing was down slightly in I-Joist but up about 4% in LVL/LSL.
Our other building products. This category includes our interior moulding business, our South American operations and the U.S. GreenFiber Joint Venture in some non-operating facilities. Overall, we were slightly positive in the first quarter of 2010 as compared to income of $1.6 million first quarter of last year. For the quarter, sales for these operations were $41 million, up 45% from the $28 million recorded in Q1 of last year. 
Some other items. We did have a small foreign exchange gain in the quarter compared to $2.6 million gain in the same quarter last year. And then investment income in the quarter was about flat between periods, with returns down significantly but cash balances were higher. Interest expense was nearly $17 million in the quarter compared to $13 million in Q1 of 2009. This is primarily due to the higher cost refinancing that we completed late in Q1 of 2009. 
Slide 8 of the presentation shows some balance sheet items. Cash, cash equivalents, investments of restricted cash were $414 million into the quarter, working capital about $520 million. We had net cash over debt of $136 million, and capital expenditures were relatively modest $4 million in the quarter. Book value per ending share was $9.73.
I do want to mention as I did in our earnings call at the end of February that we did have a balance sheet growth that occurred in Q1 and was reflected retrospectively for prior periods. This was due to a change in accounting standard. We added back our previously qualified special purpose entity, an entity called LP Plywood, that was off-balance sheet and now it's back on the balance sheet. This entity was put in place in 2003 to defer the income taxes paid on the sale of LP's southern timberlands. By adding these back, we increased our assets by $368 million, increased our liability by a like amount and reduced equity by about $1 million.
The overall transaction has been disclosed since the inception in our footnotes but is now included in the balance sheet. This is the note, the associated debt had little or no recourse to LP as it is backed by a letter of credit, which is subsequently backed by cash. 
A few other comments before give to Rick, our federal tax refund, as we discussed in our last call, we did do a rap in filing 2009 federal income tax return and received a refund of about $47 million during the quarter. The balance sheet shows the remaining income tax receivable of about $6 million, and that will come back to LP over the next year or so. On the auction rate securities, based on valuations received from third parties, we did increase in the value of this portfolio by about $10 million in the quarter. And as you know, we are continuing to pursue the litigation filed against the principal issuers of these instruments. 
With that, let me turn over to Rick.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. It is drizzling here in Nashville, but we are drawing out after a week of sunshine last week. I'm sure that you did see in the news that we had severe weather and a lot of rain in the middle Tennessee area last weekend, and we had
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. It is drizzling here in Nashville, but we are drawing out after a week of sunshine last week. I'm sure that you did see in the news that we had severe weather and a lot of rain in the middle Tennessee area last weekend, and we had plenty of, I guess, unprecedented nature. It was the worst flooding in history. I am happy to report and relieved to report that we were fortunate that no LP employee suffered significant flood damage, but the town will take some time to recover.
I want to begin my brief prepared remarks this morning by adding a little bit of color in Q1 but not be redundant to what Curt has already said. On the safety front, we got up to a great start in the year with only two recordable injuries across our system in Q1 and a TIR of 0.23. Other most significant event was that our Carthage OSB mill was the first OSB mill in history in North America to exceed 1 million incident free work hours. 
Overall, financially, we did eke out our first positive adjusted EBITDA quarter Q1 since 2006, which felt good. The housing market ended the quarter with seasonally adjusted single-family starts of about 530,000. Each of our three core businesses did improve financially from Q1 of '09, which was granted a pretty low hurdle to jump over. But they also improved over Q4 of 2009 as well.
Make a few comments on each of our reporting segments for Q1. OSB did surprise us in Q1. Our customer's needs were more robust than we had anticipated going into the quarter. Random links sprint across the six different sales regions moved to upward, $60 to $65 on the 716 [indiscernible] bases during the quarter. Because of the lag effect, which is the time between order and delivery, we weren't able to capture all of that move, but what we did capture helped us considerably. 
Our Hanceville OSB Alabama mill was down 42 days in Q1 for log outages, resulting from weather that was adverse to logging. Our TechShield Radiant Barrier OSB roof sheathing was up 50% over Q1 '09, and our TopNotch Sub-Flooring was up 24% from the same quarter last year. We did have two mills that we're indefinitely shut during the quarter, Chambord and Clark County. And the rest of our mills ran on various shifting schedules.
In Siding, our SmartSide volume was up about 20% over Q1 2009, with slightly stronger sales price due to mix, and we think that bodes well for us for the rest of the year. As Curt mentioned, our CanExel fine fiber product remains on allocation as we work to get our production scheduling back in balance. 
In Engineered Wood Products, the segment which is most heavily tied to new residential construction, we improved, which means we lost less money. At these volume levels, this is still a distressed business segment. Plaguing this business at present are the lack of starts and component raw material prices [audio gap] which are outstripping finished product pricing. 
As you know, I-Joist is made from OSB web stock and flanged lumber and LVL is made from peeled veneer. All three of these core components have increased substantially in price, more so than finished product pricing. 
In Chile, which I had an opportunity to visit in the first quarter, the earthquake affected our Lautaro mill adversely with about 17-day outage. But at present, both of our Chilean mills are running full, to feed the reconstruction efforts that is needed there. 
I'll spend a few moments looking forward in terms of what we see coming at us and then we'll open it up to questions. Obviously, the recent run-up in OSB pricing is going to positively affect the financial performance of our OSB business and LP overall in Q2. It has certainly been unexpected, but even at these demand and takeaway levels, it is very significant to us. But the housing market has experienced a welcome bump, if you will. However, from what I read, it is unlikely that substantial recovery towards the base underlying housing demand will be significant in 2010. I just reviewed a recent composite of the 2010 start forecast put together by APA, and that still doesn't break the 700,000 start level for 2010. Although RISI is still the outlier on this, having the end of the year start level at about 850,000. 
Couple of questions for us are yet unanswered. First, is how much of the current housing activity is a pull-forward cost by tax incentives. And the second is the channel building a little bit more of a position for the summer. Meanwhile, we are still looking at four large problems in the eyes of four that we have been looking at for a year now. The first is high unemployment, which last week came in at 9.9%; continued foreclosures; the excess of for-sale inventory of existing homes and in general, slower household formation. And because of these elements, we're still being quite cautious in our optimism around this recovery. 
That said, I'll turn it back over to Curt for the question period.

componenttext: Well, we had anticipated as we put our production scheduling together, a pretty lackluster first quarter, and demand came out as a little bit heavier than what we thought. We were only able to meet that demand as we had put production on. And when demand's a little bit higher than the ability to supply it, the traded commodity that moves it forward. And so it, I think one of the analysts wrote about demandless recovery, it wasn't huge. It wasn't demand that we felt back several years ago, but it was a little bit more than we could supply. That allowed our traders the opportunity to ask more for the product out in future weeks.

componenttext: Right. I continue to look at that as well, Gail. Financing continues to get in our way. We haven't had any of the buyers, the potential buyers of the two biggest assets, fall out. headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Mark, I'll take a shot at that and then if I miss something, Curt can fill in the holes. If you look at Q1, you guys get various amounts of information, but I'll refer to Random Lengths’ print. The year, North Central began on a 7/16 basis at 182.
componenttext: Yes. Mark, I'll take a shot at that and then if I miss something, Curt can fill in the holes. If you look at Q1, you guys get various amounts of information, but I'll refer to Random Lengths’ print. The year, North Central began on a 7/16 basis at 182. And I think quarter ended North Central 7/16 at 248. There are six different sales regions. And prices during the quarter varied between $10 and $15 up or down from each other in those sales regions. In the first quarter, the North Central was higher than all the other regions, except for Western Canada. So a weighted average of sales may not equal the North Central pricing that some people seem to pick and look at obsessively. There's also a lag on pricing for open market wood. The way this works is that as order files extend, an order taken in one week may not actually be delivered for four weeks. So in a climbing pricing environment, this creates a lag in terms of getting what may print on a Friday. It may take you however long your order file is out to capture that particular price. So if the market moves very, very quickly, you stay behind it. There's another influence that we had in terms of looking at that and that is that our value-added products tend to lag the market as well because the price in these products changes less rapidly. We did have a high component of value-added in Q1 with TechShield and TopNotch. And then finally, I think the other thing that influences price, particularly as price becomes higher, is that there are discounts on contracted wood on a percentage basis. So at a higher number those percentages are higher dollars. So that's what happens when the market moves very rapidly in the up direction.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, in Q1, if we take the volumes that we purchased in Q1 of 2010 and applied pricing from last year to that, we're actually, we’re slightly positive in wood costs. The problem we had in Q1 was getting the wood. There wasn't any wood available, an
componenttext: Actually, in Q1, if we take the volumes that we purchased in Q1 of 2010 and applied pricing from last year to that, we're actually, we’re slightly positive in wood costs. The problem we had in Q1 was getting the wood. There wasn't any wood available, and that's why we had the downtime in the southern mills. But in general, because we operate both, as you know, in Canada and the U.S. in the lake states, we do a lot of logging during the winter in the north and that wasn't affected by the weather at all. So our costs are actually down a little bit. And as I look forward, I think they're going to be relatively flat, maybe up a little bit in Q2, but not a lot.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010

componenttext: Rick, I don't know if you care to comment on Chile and Brazil. Maybe you can touch on the earthquakes and what that's done, if anything, to the supply chain. What you're seeing on the marketplace. And just your progress on your Chile, Brazilian strategy?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd be happy to. I think in terms of Chile, from what we can tell, it looks like about 300,000 residences were destroyed in that earthquake, which is somewhere in the neighborhood of 10 years worth of building. So in terms of what that's done for us,
componenttext: Yes. I'd be happy to. I think in terms of Chile, from what we can tell, it looks like about 300,000 residences were destroyed in that earthquake, which is somewhere in the neighborhood of 10 years worth of building. So in terms of what that's done for us, if you remember, on the last call, I said we had just started Lautaro, which is our second mill up in hopes of running it for the rest of the year. We now feel quite confident that we will run both mills full out for a considerable period of time to help in that reconstruction. So we did start Lautaro up between Christmas and New Year's. Right after the earthquake, we added the fourth shift there as quickly as possible. So both Pangui and Lautaro are running full. The other positive thing out of this catastrophe was that wood construction held up quite well. So we think that it will continue to help us in our effort to convert building practices in Chile. We did send about 4 million feet down from Canada to Chile in the immediate relief effort. And with some help to our Brazilian operation, we're moving a couple thousand cubic meters a month over from Brazil. So Chile looks to be full speed ahead with both mills for the foreseeable future, meaning, I would think at least a couple of years. In Brazil, we are running our Ponta Grossa mill at about 50% of capacity. When we bought that mill, it was in need of some improvement. We do have one dryer and one thermal oil system, which is down. And we are looking to, perhaps, start that dryer and that thermal oil system up somewhere in the fourth quarter to continue to fill in the success that we're having in selling OSB for non-construction purposes in Brazil. In a concurrent effort, we are working through the bureaucratic red tape to qualify a building system in Brazil, what we're calling an OSB building system, which is if we’re successful there would allow us to then put LP OSB into that building system. There's a huge pent-up demand in Brazil, as I talked about last year and why we went there, currently, of about 7 million homes. And the need is projected for about 18 million homes over the next decade. So we think that that's going to continue to get more attractive for us. But right now, we're caught in this bureaucratic red tape. In Brazil, they don't approve single products. In their regulatory environment, they approve building systems. So we've been working on that now for about five or six months. And hopefully, we’ll break through sometime this year.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think some of the capacity, now that you've had -- feeding the Chilean market was really ceded from North America. And I guess related to that, I'm curious on your strategy for Chambord. It seems like you have many lower cost mills in your system that w
componenttext: I think some of the capacity, now that you've had -- feeding the Chilean market was really ceded from North America. And I guess related to that, I'm curious on your strategy for Chambord. It seems like you have many lower cost mills in your system that would likely come on before Chambord would. Given your somewhat cautious statements about buying into the recovery or a strong recovery in housing starts, how do you think about the future of that mill?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, to your first point, we only moved about 4 million feet from North America down to Chile, which was to help until we could get Pangui up. To your second question, I think first on our radar, which would be obvious, is that we did spend a couple hund
componenttext: Well, to your first point, we only moved about 4 million feet from North America down to Chile, which was to help until we could get Pangui up. To your second question, I think first on our radar, which would be obvious, is that we did spend a couple hundred million dollars on building Clarke County. And that will be our most important issue to try to get utilized as the market comes back to us.

componenttext: And in terms of, Lotsen [ph] talked about this supply-related pricing increases in OSB. But what have you guys seen on the demand side, especially from your customers? Is it higher pull-throughs? Are you seeing things recover slightly faster than the current numbers indicate?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not seeing that. What we have felt so far is just a slight imbalance between what we thought we could produce and what was being asked of us. But in terms of any great underlying pull, I mean I think the numbers speak for themself. We finished the fir
componenttext: I'm not seeing that. What we have felt so far is just a slight imbalance between what we thought we could produce and what was being asked of us. But in terms of any great underlying pull, I mean I think the numbers speak for themself. We finished the first quarter at an annualized rate of 530,000 single starts. So that's not terribly robust. What we're trying to figure out is, was any of that pull-forward from these tax incentives, and then what's going to happen in historically Q3, which is prime building time. But we've seen permits go up just a little bit, but nothing that would knock your socks off. So as I said in my prepared remarks, I don't have a consensus forecast that says single-family starts or all-in that we're even going to crack 700,000 this year with RISI being the outlier and they're saying we’ll end the year at 870. Right now, we're in a wait-and-see mode and we're being quite careful.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the only thing I would say to that is we did see both January and February starts get adjusted upwards in later months. And I wouldn't be surprised if March gets adjusted upward.
componenttext: Well, the only thing I would say to that is we did see both January and February starts get adjusted upwards in later months. And I wouldn't be surprised if March gets adjusted upward.

componenttextpreview: What we said for 2010 is would be in the $20 million to $25 million. And I have no expectations it’s going to be different than that. Next year, probably the biggest piece is the completion of the Brazilian acquisition. We have 75% of that mill and then
componenttext: What we said for 2010 is would be in the $20 million to $25 million. And I have no expectations it’s going to be different than that. Next year, probably the biggest piece is the completion of the Brazilian acquisition. We have 75% of that mill and then there is a simultaneous put-call in November of next year. So I’d anticipate we'd pick up the other 25% of that mill. And that's in the neighborhood of probably 18 to 25, somewhere in there. That would certainly be in the plan. I think we've talked about some of the maintenance we need to do on the presses, which are that's probably the biggest maintenance expense you have in OSB mill. And we do have a press or two that we’re going to have to look at over the next two years. I don't know if that'll be a 2011 or 2012. And those are generally right around $15 million to redo all that. I don’t have anything of great significance because we have existing capacity in front of each one of our businesses.

componenttext: Well, the two that are in line are Clarke County and Chambord. And I think what Rick said is we’d certainly like to get a return on our investment in Clarke County. componenttext: Yes. It was a 2003 timber sale that we did. So there’s a note receivable and note payable with an investment by LP of about $45 million. So the receivable is greater than the payable. When we did that in 2003, the rules required us to make that an off-balance sheet transaction, a qualified special-purpose entity. They changed the rules effective January 1, which changed the rules back to where it used to be. And so we had to add those back onto the balance sheet.
