headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess Rick, I’ll be curious on how you assess inventories in the channel, whether they’d be producers, wholesalers, distributors, builders. If the channel wants to build working capital, do they have a liquidity needed to invest in working capital o
componenttext: I guess Rick, I’ll be curious on how you assess inventories in the channel, whether they’d be producers, wholesalers, distributors, builders. If the channel wants to build working capital, do they have a liquidity needed to invest in working capital or are we looking at a pretty lean channel?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our sense with our customers is that they are very lean right now and our belief is that they will, if they have any fat left at all, they will lean out by the end of the year to get their numbers right. Our demand is as I said in our prepared comments, d
componenttext: Our sense with our customers is that they are very lean right now and our belief is that they will, if they have any fat left at all, they will lean out by the end of the year to get their numbers right. Our demand is as I said in our prepared comments, did pick up a little bit on the repair and remodel side in October. Actually, we liked the months that we had in Siding very much. We’re back towards where our plan was, which was a good sign, but I think that we don’t sense any of our customers taking an early at this point in time.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe last question if I could for Curt. The interest expense was a little lower than we thought. If I annualize that number and take it as a percent of your long-term debt, its sub 6%, presumably you’re not getting a whole lot of interest income on you
componenttext: Maybe last question if I could for Curt. The interest expense was a little lower than we thought. If I annualize that number and take it as a percent of your long-term debt, its sub 6%, presumably you’re not getting a whole lot of interest income on your cash balance. Anything else going on in that interest expense number, is that a good quarterly run rate going forward?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: What happens in the interest expense and the interest income is that the accounting literature forces us to report those on separate lines. So, you do have the impact of those timber notes in there. That’s what I explained. The reason the interest expen
componenttext: What happens in the interest expense and the interest income is that the accounting literature forces us to report those on separate lines. So, you do have the impact of those timber notes in there. That’s what I explained. The reason the interest expense went down is we did pay off or we did receive $115 million, $116 million, on one of the timber notes and we paid off on $113 million. So both the income and expense side went down by about $3 million between Q2 and Q3. So, you really should look at the long-term debt footnote in the 10-K and I will give it to you, but the impact of those timber notes is just really throw those around and it’s grossed up, it’s on both sides.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Very good. Thanks, guys.
componenttext: Okay. Very good. Thanks, guys.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Pete.
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Pete.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Chercover of D.A. Davidson. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Chercover of D.A. Davidson. Please go ahead.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Start with Curt. Can you discuss the share count it seems of moving around, is that due to some of the debt that you’ve retired in the quarter and may be just tell us what share count we should use?
componenttext: Good morning, everyone. Start with Curt. Can you discuss the share count it seems of moving around, is that due to some of the debt that you’ve retired in the quarter and may be just tell us what share count we should use?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the share count has moved around because of two things; one, the equity offering that we did last September is a piece of it. The second piece of that is the warrants that are being exercised. It didn’t affect this quarter because we are in a loss
componenttext: Well, the share count has moved around because of two things; one, the equity offering that we did last September is a piece of it. The second piece of that is the warrants that are being exercised. It didn’t affect this quarter because we are in a loss position. It seems really from the dilution standpoint some of those were non-dilutive or were dilutive, so they didn’t get counted in the share count. What is the share count, Becky, at the end of the quarter? 138...

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: So that was a function of the loss.
componenttext: So that was a function of the loss.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was a function of the loss.
componenttext: Yes, it was a function of the loss.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Perhaps an update on your auction rate securities, are you still getting paid on those? Can you discuss what’s going on in the lawsuit?
componenttext: Perhaps an update on your auction rate securities, are you still getting paid on those? Can you discuss what’s going on in the lawsuit?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’re getting paid on all, but the one auction rate I think they stopped paying about 18 months ago. The rest of them were all paying on time. The lawsuit is as disclosed in the 10-K, it’s really in the same point it was before. We have one lawsuit th
componenttext: We’re getting paid on all, but the one auction rate I think they stopped paying about 18 months ago. The rest of them were all paying on time. The lawsuit is as disclosed in the 10-K, it’s really in the same point it was before. We have one lawsuit that’s been moved to New York and one still is in the Ninth District and we’re pursuing those and hopefully we’ll be successful.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Aren’t most of those ARS coming due sometime in your future?
componenttext: Aren’t most of those ARS coming due sometime in your future?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, they have a long tails on them. Some of them are out to 20-20, 20-25.
componenttext: No, they have a long tails on them. Some of them are out to 20-20, 20-25.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then going back to Chip’s question. It doesn’t sound like you’re planning to run anymore facilities in 2011 than you did in 2010. So how do you flex it? Are you planning to run only two shifts in certain plants or how would you?
componenttext: And then going back to Chip’s question. It doesn’t sound like you’re planning to run anymore facilities in 2011 than you did in 2010. So how do you flex it? Are you planning to run only two shifts in certain plants or how would you?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have shifting arrangements that are different by mill and by business, but basically the way we set up our OSB businesses is we have a primary mill and a secondary mill, and so we try to focus more of our downtime on our secondary mill in each region t
componenttext: We have shifting arrangements that are different by mill and by business, but basically the way we set up our OSB businesses is we have a primary mill and a secondary mill, and so we try to focus more of our downtime on our secondary mill in each region than our primary mill. But that’s basically on a week-by-week basis in terms of looking at what our order file is and then adjusting our run rate to that in each particular region. So, some mills are running two weeks on, two weeks off, some mills are running reduced shifting, some mills are running full well, another mill barely runs. So, it’s different in each region based upon what we think the takeaway is going to be in that particular area.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the only difference this year is your log inventories going into it?
componenttext: So the only difference this year is your log inventories going into it?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s the only difference that we have that we’re doing purposefully heading into the spring.
componenttext: That’s the only difference that we have that we’re doing purposefully heading into the spring.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Very good. Thanks very much.
componenttext: Very good. Thanks very much.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research. Please go ahead.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Trying to understand if the 700,000 housing start environment plays out and your view on repair/remodeling plays out as well. Order of magnitude what would that do to OSB demand do you think 2011 versus 2010?
componenttext: Thank you. Trying to understand if the 700,000 housing start environment plays out and your view on repair/remodeling plays out as well. Order of magnitude what would that do to OSB demand do you think 2011 versus 2010?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we use market as kind of a thumb, look at that as each 100,000 housing start is about 1 billion square feet at capacity on the housing side and then if we get incremental repair and remodel demand, it would add to that.
componenttext: Well, we use market as kind of a thumb, look at that as each 100,000 housing start is about 1 billion square feet at capacity on the housing side and then if we get incremental repair and remodel demand, it would add to that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: So less than 5% perhaps, 5% increase?
componenttext: So less than 5% perhaps, 5% increase?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we’re not doing 20 billion today. I think the number for 2010 is likely to end up between 15 billion and 16 billion for the year. So, it would be less than that.
componenttext: Well, we’re not doing 20 billion today. I think the number for 2010 is likely to end up between 15 billion and 16 billion for the year. So, it would be less than that.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know that you’ve done a lot of work to reduce the fixed cost basis on your system. So when we think about the impact that increasing volumes can have, how much of additional profitability beyond what the profit per unit you are showing at current pric
componenttext: I know that you’ve done a lot of work to reduce the fixed cost basis on your system. So when we think about the impact that increasing volumes can have, how much of additional profitability beyond what the profit per unit you are showing at current prices. Can we think as being levered by that incremental volume?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: You have to look at that by business. In Siding, every unit of Siding that we sell from a volume perspective adds to our profitability. For both EWP and OSB in Q2, the additional volume at the pricing that was in the market would not have increased profit
componenttext: You have to look at that by business. In Siding, every unit of Siding that we sell from a volume perspective adds to our profitability. For both EWP and OSB in Q2, the additional volume at the pricing that was in the market would not have increased profitability at all.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: In Q3?
componenttext: In Q3?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: In Q3. But as you go forward, what you can see is the impact of incremental demand in Q2 for example and what pricing did with the dramatic improvement in the earnings in really all three of the businesses in Q2 with not much more demand, but incremental
componenttext: In Q3. But as you go forward, what you can see is the impact of incremental demand in Q2 for example and what pricing did with the dramatic improvement in the earnings in really all three of the businesses in Q2 with not much more demand, but incremental demand.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: It would cash positive, even at Q3 but it wouldn’t be EBIT positive, is that right, the difference between the depreciation?
componenttext: It would cash positive, even at Q3 but it wouldn’t be EBIT positive, is that right, the difference between the depreciation?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right, it would be cash positive in OSB, but would not have been in EWP.
componenttext: Right, it would be cash positive in OSB, but would not have been in EWP.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: The DD&A actually goes up when you are running more because the way you account for it?
componenttext: The DD&A actually goes up when you are running more because the way you account for it?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. We account per units of production. Rick made the point, but just let me give you much numbers. Our production volumes were so low in Q3 compared to Q3 of last year, just to give you an idea, OSB was only up 3%. So, it wasn’t up much. Siding prod
componenttext: Right. We account per units of production. Rick made the point, but just let me give you much numbers. Our production volumes were so low in Q3 compared to Q3 of last year, just to give you an idea, OSB was only up 3%. So, it wasn’t up much. Siding production was down 25% Q3 of ‘09 to Q3 of ‘10. I-Joist is down 43% and Laminated Veneer Lumber, Laminated Strand Lumber is down 23%. So, to have basically comparable results with that much less production volume shows you what we have done at the facilities with our flexible scheduling and with trying to reduce our fixed cost.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: How much of it though is the flexible scheduling, so that when the volume picks up it doesn’t all flow to the bottom-line versus how much of it is a reduction of fixed cost so that when volume picks up it would all flow to the bottom-line, that’s kind
componenttext: How much of it though is the flexible scheduling, so that when the volume picks up it doesn’t all flow to the bottom-line versus how much of it is a reduction of fixed cost so that when volume picks up it would all flow to the bottom-line, that’s kind of where I am trying to get to?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’m not sure I can give you that answer. From a fixed cost standpoint or from a variable cost standpoint if we have to increase shifts, obviously, you’re going to have a cost associated with that and the other fixed cost that you should gather most of
componenttext: I’m not sure I can give you that answer. From a fixed cost standpoint or from a variable cost standpoint if we have to increase shifts, obviously, you’re going to have a cost associated with that and the other fixed cost that you should gather most of that, but I don’t have a percentage for you.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Okay, thank you.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) Your next question comes from the line of Paul Quinn of RBC Capital Markets. Please go ahead.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) Your next question comes from the line of Paul Quinn of RBC Capital Markets. Please go ahead.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, good morning. Just a couple of questions and a comment. Just on South America, I’m just trying to understand the upside and it sounds like you’ve described it as most of the OSB right now is from immediate repair. If the Chilean governmen
componenttext: Yes, thanks, good morning. Just a couple of questions and a comment. Just on South America, I’m just trying to understand the upside and it sounds like you’ve described it as most of the OSB right now is from immediate repair. If the Chilean government turns around and starts to look at increase in their reconstruction which we expect going forward, how do you take advantage of that with Chilean mills operating on a 100%?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: We take advantage over the couple ways. We did ship down some product out of North America to help them with a short-term lift right after the earthquake. Obviously, with the production schedules that we are running in the U.S., we have the opportunity to
componenttext: We take advantage over the couple ways. We did ship down some product out of North America to help them with a short-term lift right after the earthquake. Obviously, with the production schedules that we are running in the U.S., we have the opportunity to do that. The weak U.S. dollar is kind of an opportunity for that, but primarily the way we’re going to do that as Rick said we’re only running our Brazilian mill at 50%, but we can easily bring product from Brazil into Chile and that’s probably the first place we would go. The second place we would go is looking at our OSB operations in the North America to support that surge in demand.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: As well what will happen is that that product has been used over the last few months just for these temporary shelters there’ll be less of a demand for that, and that product will go then into satisfying real home construction. We had about 500,000 home
componenttext: As well what will happen is that that product has been used over the last few months just for these temporary shelters there’ll be less of a demand for that, and that product will go then into satisfying real home construction. We had about 500,000 homes that were affected in Chile, which is somewhere in the neighborhood of two to three years of supply. So, the product has been going into temporary shelters and packaging and just basic emergency relief will transfer them into actually building structures.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the other way that we’re looking at that is Chile exported products to other countries in South America as well as into Asia, and we will try to satisfy that demand from the Brazilian mills or the North American mills.
componenttext: I think the other way that we’re looking at that is Chile exported products to other countries in South America as well as into Asia, and we will try to satisfy that demand from the Brazilian mills or the North American mills.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: What’s the timing on the Chilean government change to move to more reconstruction?
componenttext: What’s the timing on the Chilean government change to move to more reconstruction?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think just a couple of months, they just came in and looked at, they wanted to take a look at how they were allocating out this work. I think they may have found some things that they didn’t particularly like from the last administration, and they wer
componenttext: I think just a couple of months, they just came in and looked at, they wanted to take a look at how they were allocating out this work. I think they may have found some things that they didn’t particularly like from the last administration, and they were, before they went whole hog on that they wanted to clean up a few of those things. So, we didn’t really expect that to put things off for more than just a few months.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: The miners are safe. They have to turn their attention to something else.
componenttext: The miners are safe. They have to turn their attention to something else.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the signing, can you remind us the split between SmartSide and Canexel and sort of your expectation for Canexel product line going forward. It seems like the Canadian housing market is slowing down here?
componenttext: Just on the signing, can you remind us the split between SmartSide and Canexel and sort of your expectation for Canexel product line going forward. It seems like the Canadian housing market is slowing down here?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Canexel is on allocation. So I don’t anticipate that there’ll be enough of a slowdown in the Canadian market to put the Canexel product line in any kind of a shape where we won’t sell it out. So, we’re not looking there, where that may affect us m
componenttext: Canexel is on allocation. So I don’t anticipate that there’ll be enough of a slowdown in the Canadian market to put the Canexel product line in any kind of a shape where we won’t sell it out. So, we’re not looking there, where that may affect us more as we do sell a lot of engineered wood products up there and if housing slows down then that will affect our takeaways in engineered wood.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a split on sales or operating earnings between the two?
componenttext: Just a split on sales or operating earnings between the two?

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: We haven’t provided that information. It is a single line and each derivative runs Canexel and then we’ve got five facilities in the U.S. that produce SmartSide.
componenttext: We haven’t provided that information. It is a single line and each derivative runs Canexel and then we’ve got five facilities in the U.S. that produce SmartSide.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just maybe a comment, I understand the bias for football analogies described in your operational performance, but looking at the national predators at 5, 5 and 3, I think they are probably a better comp.
componenttext: And then just maybe a comment, I understand the bias for football analogies described in your operational performance, but looking at the national predators at 5, 5 and 3, I think they are probably a better comp.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well said Paul, but I’m not a hockey fan, so I’m not paying any attention.
componenttext: Well said Paul, but I’m not a hockey fan, so I’m not paying any attention.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, guys. Good luck.
componenttext: Thanks, guys. Good luck.
